title: What is the last day I can file a motion to lift stay in bankruptcy action?
question: I have filed an adversary complaint challenging dischargeability of a fraud judgment and asking the court to return the case to state court so that I can proceed with the writ and garnishment, but was told that I would probably have to file a motion to lift stay. The creditors claim file date is Monday and I need to know if I must file the motion prior to that date.
answers: You have filed an adversary proceeding here, and not a proof of claim. If the debtor's case is a Chapter 7 case, you would litigate your adversary proceeding through a trial. If you try the adversary proceeding, and if the U.S. Bankruptcy judge rules that the debt is nondischargeable, you can collect this debt from the debtor after the discharge order is entered in the case. The discharge injunction then would not apply to your debt, and you would be free to resume collection activities in the state court. This is not a DIY project, though. You should hire an experienced bankruptcy attorney to represent you. If you lose your adversary proceeding, the debtor can recover costs and attorneys fees from you. The debtor can file a bill of costs against you if you lose the adversary case, and come after you to collect the costs and fees. This is a specialized area of the law, and bankruptcy courts take an independent view of fraud, and how a fraud judgment in a state court should be treated. Go get some advice from an experienced local bankruptcy attorney.

Question not clear. You refer to "claims bar date" and "motion to lift stay"
Claims Bar Date is deadline for creditors to file a proof of claim. This date is included on notice sent to all creditors.
Deadline to object to discharge is different. Not relevant in this case if you have already filed an adversary.
Not likely any BK judge will allow you to obtain writ or garnishment prior to deciding the adversary case.
Deadline is date the automatic stay is lifted. Generally this is date all administration of the case has been concluded.
BK litigation requires specialized knowledge. Consult BK counsel.

Quickly, locate a BK atty using the AVVO tab, "Find a Lawyer". Don't waste precious time trying to become a BK lawyer in 30 days. The BK court will not allow you to pursue collection efforts in state court during the automatic stay issued by the BK court. Unless you can afford to lose your case, get a lawyer, pay him for his work to preserve your claim against the debtor. If nothing else, the lawyer can assess the likelihood of your being successful in your claim.

No. I'm not sure what you mean by the "creditors claim file date". The Claims Bar Date (I assume that's what you meant) is the deadline for creditors to file a proof of claim, but that would only be set in a Chapter 7 case if the Trustee is liquidating assets and disbursing funds to the creditors.

If you're referring to the deadline to object to the discharge of debts, that's irrelevant for you since, according to your facts, you've already filed the adversary.

As far as the Motion for Relief From Stay, I don't see any way a bankruptcy judge is going to allow you to do a writ or garnishment prior to you prevailing on your adversary case, but I suppose you can try. The deadline for doing that is prior to the termination of the automatic stay. After that date, there would be no need for you to seek relief from stay.

The automatic stay terminates as to some actions upon entry of the discharge, but for most it terminates when the case is closed--which occurs after discharge and once all administration of the case, including all adversary proceedings, are completed.
